Title: Abujmadh operation pricks Reds’ pride, plan
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Nagpur: The Abujmadh operation against Maoists along the Maharashtra-Chhattisgarh border on November 30 last year is learnt to have dealt a decisive blow to the rebels. It led to the exposure of their significant strategic guerrilla warfare base. Two of their cadres were also neutralized in the operation conducted by C-60 commandos .

The operation, which took place across Indravati river in Chhattisgarh, led to busting of a training camp where Maoists were grooming recruits with arms and physical training. The place, part of the Maoist-dominated Abujmadh, is also known to be the location where several rebel hideouts are present. Abujmadh is also part of Central India’s almost inaccessible and sparsely populated ‘Dandakaranya region’.

Around a year ago, C-60 commandos had stormed a camp in Abujmadh where, for the first time, four horses were seized. The horses were used by senior Maoists cadres in the hideouts as a mode of transport on the forested stretch. A couple of senior cadres had managed to flee.

SP Shailesh Balkawade said the location where the latest camp was busted is strategically crucial for the Maoists who thought that security forces could not access it. “The raid by security forces in one of their safe havens shocked the Maoists. Apart from the casualties, arms and ammunitions of Maoists were also seized. The operation was unbelievable for the Maoists,” he said.

The camping site was a forested stretch where Maoists conducted their internal meetings routinely, halting comfortably for a day or two without having to worry about being found. “The south sub-zonal bureau committee members from south Chhattisgarh’s Bastar, Bijapur and other districts met the south sub-zonal bureau committee which had Gadchiroli district under it. The two committees met at this point and discussed their future plans, assessed the current situation related to the strength and movements of the security forces and other issues,” said Balkawade.

“It was a regular practice for Maoists to gather villagers from adjoining hamlets to attend camps here and help them,” said the SP.

Balkawade also said that the place raided by the C-60 commandos also served as the gateway for Abujmadh. “Senior cadres like Bhupathi and Tarakka visited these camps and also participated in meetings. They also used this place to enter or exit Abujmadh for medical and other emergencies,” he said.

“Now, the Maoists have to think many times before considering the place as a safe haven,” he added.

Title: Zero response to NMC’s move to regularize mobile towers
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Nagpur: Mobile phone companies have failed to regularize 751 mobile towers across the city. The companies have also defaulted on NMC ’s property tax to the tune of Rs8.63 crore.

The one-year grace period to regularize mobile towers will end this month. Now, the NMC has decided to levy fine on property owners for allowing installation of mobile towers without mandatory permissions.

A senior NMC town planning department official told TOI that all mobile phone companies had erected towers on private properties by not taking permission from the NMC.

Following a petition in 2014, the high court had directed the NMC to prepare a policy to regularize existing mobile towers. The HC had also asked the NMC not to take any coercive action, including seizing of towers, as it will hamper mobile phone services.

In 2018, the state government had issued a circular directing the NMC to prepare a policy for the same. Subsequently, the town planning department prepared three categories to regularize the existing towers — occupancy certificate and sanction plan, sanction plan but no occupancy certificate and nothing among the two categories.

But with zero response, the department in February last year extended the period to regularize mobile phone towers by inviting applications from owners of cellular companies till January 2020, the official said.

Still it received very poor response as only 169 applications were submitted till the end of December 2019. But all the applications are short of the requisite documents for regularization.

Similar conditions will also be considered while giving permissions for erecting new towers, the official said.

Now, the town planning department has decided to invoke sections 53 and 54 of the Maharashtra Town Planning Act which empowers the civic body to force the owners of the buildings to regularize mobile towers or the NMC can levy fine as per ready reckoner rate of the value of the property.

The norms allow the NMC to levy penalty up to four times of the ready reckoner value of the property where mobile towers were erected.

Title: Most crimes under influence of liquor: Study
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: While the city is yet to recover from the brutal gangrape and murder of 27-year-old veterinary doctor Disha by four inebriated youth, who even forced alcohol into her mouth, a new study on violent criminals housed at Chanchalguda Central Prison revealed that most crimes were committed under the influence of alcohol.The study, carried out jointly by Institute of Mental Health, Osmania Medical College and Institute of Medical Sciences Adilabad, aimed at finding mental health co-morbidities in 65 offenders. The researchers found that only 3% of the offenders had some psychiatric problems. The study ‘Crime Characteristics and Psychiatric Morbidity in Violent Offenders’ included participating offenders, involved in crimes like murder and attempt to murder, dacoity, rape, robbery, abetment to suicide etc. In conclusion, the study suggested measures to control alcohol dependency, thereby curb such crimes.The aim was to understand various socio-demographic factors, crime characteristics and psychiatric morbidity in violent offenders as violence and psychopathology were believed to be interrelated. “Persons with mental illness can present with high violent behaviour and, on the other hand, criminals can have co morbid psychopathology. By analysing factors responsible for violent criminal behaviour and whether psychopathology is contributing to the same, a criminal profile for predicting recidivism in violent offenders,” the study added.The researchers — Dr Anitha Rayirala, Dr K Sudha Rani , Dr Divija Bunga and Dr Umashankar — said in the study: “It is remarkable to know that no one had other psychiatric symptoms apart from substance dependence and intoxication at the time of commission of crime. We found 58.4% subjects with alcohol dependence, and most of the crimes were committed on relatives, mostly spouses. Majority were directly or indirectly due to use of alcohol most probably, since no other psychiatric illness or underlying personality disorders could be diagnosed. Only 3.3% had antisocial personality traits, which is not significant.”Researchers said, “More awareness programmes and campaigns regarding influence of alcohol on crimes can be conducted with the help of police, government, private organisations and media, especially in vulnerable and at risk population for crime, which would indirectly decrease alcohol intake in vulnerable population and decrease crime rate.”

Title: Police thrash unruly drunk revellers in Sircilla
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Representative image

SIRCILLA: Police thrashed a group of New Year revellers for creating nuisance in an inebriated condition and assaulting two men —Srinivas and Kumar — with iron rods in Sircilla in the early hours of Wednesday.

According to police, they received an alert about miscreants causing nuisance near HP Petrol Pump in Sircilla town at 1am. “Our teams, conducting drunken driving checks and on patrolling duty, rushed to the spot and noticed that a group of youngsters, carrying iron rods, chain and sticks, were roaming on the Karimnagar-Sircilla road. They had assaulted and injured two men and also tried to barge into a house,” Sircilla town circle inspector Venkata Narsaiah said.

On seeing police, some members of the group fled from the spot and three miscreants were nabbed. “They were under the influence of alcohol and did not cooperate with police. Our teams had to use batons to control them,” the CI added.

Two video clips, where police were seen thrashing three youngsters using batons and a stick, went viral on social media, mocking cops for their ‘friendly policing’ methods.

Sircilla superintendent of police (SP) Rahul Hegde said the miscreants were cutting cake on the road side near the petrol pump when an argument broke out between them and another group, who came to fill petrol in their vehicles. “During the argument over a petty issue, the miscreants, who were cutting cake, assaulted the members of other group with iron rods. They further caused panic by trying to barge into a house. The video of police using batons was circulated on the Internet , but the video of the miscreants assaulting people using iron rod, chain and a stick and creating panic on the street was not put up,” the SP said.

According to police, the accused also broke beer bottles on the road. “Based on the complaint of Srinivas, we booked a case against Sone, 20, an unemployed youth who discontinued engineering, and four of his associates under Sections 323 (voluntarily causing hurt.), 324 (voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means), 506 (criminal intimidation), 148 (rioting armed with deadly weapon), 186 (obstructing public servant from discharging his duty) r/w 149 of the IPC,” the CI said. Some of the accused have been reportedly taken into custody.

Title: States get ready to conduct Phase-IV tiger monitoring, kick off in Maha on Jan 15
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Nagpur: In order to bring the minimum number more close to the estimated population of tigers, the National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) has asked tiger-bearing states to conduct Phase-IV monitoring.

“The objective is to at least obtain minimum number of tigers in a tiger reserve. But areas outside the reserves are equally important, especially from viewpoint of gene flow. While All India Tiger Estimation (AITE) is about estimation every four years, Phase-IV is an annual affair,” said NTCA member-secretary Anup Kumar Nayak.

“We have started training of staff and collection of required number of camera traps, coordination with states and preparatory meetings are going on. The NTCA will fund this exercise from centrally sponsored scheme (CSS) for procurement of field equipment and capacity building,” said Nayak.

As per the analysis of AITE-2018 data, more than 80% (2,461) of the 2,967 tigers were individually identified/photo-captured as minimum numbers of tigers in the country. “Phase-IV monitoring is an opportunity for tiger states to conduct the exercise for current year to bring minimum number closer to the estimated number,” adds Nayak.

Pertinently, the NTCA is yet to release the number of tigers present in sanctuaries and reserves across India. The break-up of 2,967 was to be given in August and then before December 31 last year.

As per the mandate of Phase-IV, the states will conduct the exercise themselves, though support for capacity building, training, and hand-holding of field staff will be provided by the NTCA’s regional offices and NGOs.

The count will be done as per the same specification as per AITE-2018 where grid size of 2sqkm was taken to place camera traps. The exercise was supposed to start from October 2018 till May 15, 2020 but states are yet to formulate schedules.

In Maharashtra, the exercise is expected to start from January 15. As per the 4th cycle of AITE-2018, the state has 312 tigers, a rise by 122 tigers from 2014 when the number was 190.

State’s chief wildlife warden Nitin H Kakodkar said, “A meeting was held on December 27, in which all modalities were discussed. The exercise will find out density of herbivores, carnivore signs followed by installation of camera traps. The 5-day schedule will involve walking on transect line (Phase-I) too. We will involve sensitized individuals and NGOs in the exercise.”

Kakodkar informed that in fringe areas of Melghat tiger reserve the exercise has already started. Training is being given by Wildlife Institute of India (WII) researchers who are working on various projects in the region.

“We are also involving Wildlife Research & Conservation Society (WRCS), Pune, and Wildlife Conservation Society (WCT), Mumbai. They will work in areas outside tiger reserves. Pench field director Ravikiran Govekar has been appointed as nodal officer for Phase-IV,” he added.

Govekar said the exercise will be undertaken in 28 areas including protected areas (PAs) and also sanctuaries like Pranhita & Chaprala in Gadchiroli, Painganga in Yavatmal and Ghodazari in Brahmapuri.

Areas outside PAs like Brahmapuri, Wadsa, Central & West Chanda, Nagpur, Pandharkawda, Bhandara, Sawantwadi, Muktai Nagar (Jalgaon) will also be covered. All FDCM divisions in Chandrapur district have been included, he added.

Due to left-wing extremism threat, no camera trapping will be done in Pranhita and Chaprala. In these areas, sign survey, scat collection and line transect exercise will be carried out.

“The line transect exercise in relatively low density areas like Painganga, Pranhita, Tipeshwar etc is also to find out scientifically the prey density as a preparatory phase for conservation translocation in future,” said Govekar.

Govekar further added, “It is possible that there may be tiger bearing areas which did not record presence of tigers during the survey period. In Phase-IV, we will cover them.”

THE PLAN

* Phase IV involves estimating population of tigers and its prey

* Intensive monitoring of tiger source populations in tiger reserves and PAs in each tiger landscape complex will be done.

* Camera trap density one pair per 2 sqkm will be installed

* Minimum trap nights of 1,000 per 100 sqkm

* 25 pairs of cameras in 100 sqkm for 60 days

* Transects line to be minimum of 2km length

* Obtaining minimum tiger numbers through DNA analysis from scats in select areas

Title: RFSL conducts 40 tests in 25 days in minor’s rape and murder case
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Nagpur: The Regional Forensic Science Laboratory (RFSL) on Thursday handed over its DNA test findings in a minor girl’s rape and murder case to the rural police after completing 40 tests in just 25 days. The rape and murder, which took place in December last year, had triggered outrage in Kalmeshwar tehsil.

Police had coordinated with RFSL for gathering evidence from the crime spot immediately after the five-year-old girl was found raped and murdered at a farm in a village, around 40km from Nagpur, in the tehsil.

After submitting the exhibits, superintendent of police (SP) Rakesh Ola and his team had sought the DNA report in the quickest possible time.

Rural police have suggested name of senior counsel Prashant Sathianathan to the government for appointing as special public prosecutor to conduct the trial before the fast track court.

It is reliably learnt that the charge sheet is being prepared under SP Ola and addl SP Monica Raut.

Armed with the DNA report, the rural police is learnt to be gearing up to submit a legally strong charge sheet to ensure capital punishment in the case as per the amended rule under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012.

The district women and child welfare committee, along with district child protection officer, had visited the place after the incident. Following the visit, the defunct taluka-level child protection committee at Kalmeshwar was revived and awareness programmes started for minors on avoiding sexual exploitations.

It’s reliably learnt that RFSL’s deputy director Vijay Thakare had guided senior police officials at the spot through video calling for collecting evidence in a proper manner. Thakare ensured the process of collecting the exhibits was completed in a legal manner.

The girl was befriended by one Sanjay Puri, now behind bars after his arrest in the case, who had followed her to the farm before allegedly attacking her on December 6 last year. He had pinned down the girl to force himself upon her.

According to sources, the girl’s screaming and resistance had taken Puri by surprise. One of the girl’s relatives who was working in the vicinity had failed to hear the victim’s screams.

As the victim kept fighting, Puri allegedly assaulted her with a stone until she had fallen silent. He then fled the spot leaving the body there. Though an outsider for the village, he did not flee the village or dispose off the body. Puri was nabbed by Kalmeshwar police just when he was making plans to flee.

Police had a hard time in bringing the situation under control after the rape and murder came to fore. Agitators had also called bandh at the taluka a day after the incident.

Title: Kashmir fire heroes among 30 honoured by Shah
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Nagpur: Thirty fire service officials, including six heroes from Jammu and Kashmir, were honoured with gallantry awards at the hands of Union Home minister Amit Shah during investiture ceremony at National Fire Service College (NFSC) at Raj Nagar on Thursday.

Of the six from J&K, Abdul Majid Wani was conferred the top award posthumously. Total 11 heroes comprising a team of nine from Ludhiana alone, lost their lives in fire and rescue operations between December 2017 and March this year in different parts of the country. Rest belonged to Kerala, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal and Mumbai. So far, the awards used to be handed over by respective governors in their home state.

Wani’s son Jan Mohammad Wani (32), who works as a government officer, was the first to receive the medal from Shah. “This is the honour given to us by the nation. Life has been very difficult without him (Wani). We miss him every day. It was a big shock when he went for work as usual but never returned. We are proud he laid down his life to save people and their assets,” said Jan.

Union minister Nitin Gadkari, MoS for Home affairs Nitayanand Rai, leader of opposition Devendra Fadnavis, DG Fire Service Nageshwar Rao, DG NDRF SN Pradhan, NMC fire officer Rajendra Uchake, VNIT chairman Vishram Jamdar and director Pramod Padole and others were present.

Shah, who is called the brain behind abrogation of Article 370 in J&K, said the fire safety and disaster management had been neglected until 2014. “Prime minister Narendra Modi gave special attention on these two sectors and in four years after 2016, NDRF and fire service have been strengthened across the country,” he said.

The home minister said the two forces have been able to minimize damage to human lives and their assets to a large extent. “In three recent cyclones, just 64 people were killed. It looks like a big figure and I agree that not a single citizen must lose his life but a single supercyclone in Odisha had killed 10,000,” he said.

Taking potshots at Congress, the BJP heavyweight said during their time, projects would drag on for years while under Modi government they are completed on time referring to upcoming NDRF Academy on Koradi Road for which he laid the foundation stone from NFSC campus. “First Congress government used to lay the foundation, second would allot funds followed by starting the work and completion by the fourth. I have got a word from DG that the academy would be ready in 18 months,” Shah said.

NFSC campus work had started in 2010 and dragged on for over 9 years. Shah dedicated the 43-acre state-of-the-art NFSC campus to nation on the occasion.

Reiterating Modi’s stand, Shah said India’s will be 5 trillion economy in next five years though we are trying to do it before 75th anniversary of Independence.

Title: MHA’s J&K-Ladakh desk to handle matters related to Ayodhya
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

File photo

NEW DELHI: The Union home ministry has merged its internal security-I division — which was handling matters relating to security clearances, communal harmony and Ayodhya-related court cases — with internal security-II division — which dealt with mutual legal assistance pacts, extradition requests & National Security Act matters — as part of an exercise to reorganise its divisions. The merged division will be called “internal security division,” the ministry said in an office order issued on December 31, 2019.

Importantly, all files concerning Ayodhya matters and related court judgments will henceforth be put up by the deputy secretary in charge of national integration, a subject matter of internal security-I division, to additional secretary (Jammu, Kashmir & Ladakh affairs) through joint secretary (JKL). “This is for sheer administrative ease. The joint secretary of the merged internal security division, Punya Salila Srivastava, has too many matters to handle in wake of the reorganisation, apart from the women’s safety division she is also in charge of,” a home minister officer said adding that national integration wing would continue to be part of the internal security division as before.

The entrusting of separate charge for Ayodhya matters to AS(JKL) comes even as the home ministry is working on contours of the trust it needs to set up by February, as directed by the Supreme Court, for construction of Ram temple at the Ayodhya site. Besides, an alternative piece of land for the mosque needs to be identified. This would mean considerable amount of work in the coming days, an officer said pointing to the possible reason why the home ministry decided not to burden joint secretary (internal security) with Ayodhya-related matters.

As per the office order issued by the ministry with respect to the reorganisation of divisions and allocation of work at the level of joint secretary, all files/papers of additional secretary in charge of police modernisation, would henceforth be routed through secretary (border management).

Title: AWBI warns civic body for catching stray dogs with ‘metal pincers’
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Indore: The Animal Welfare Board of India (AWBI) has issued a warning to Dewas Municipal Corporation (DMC) for allegedly capturing stray dogs with metal pincers .

The board has directed the corporation to stop catching of stray dogs by metal tongs. The civic body has also been asked to take appropriate action and share about the action taken by it with the board.

The warning has been issued as animal activists of Dewas had complained against DMC staff for allegedly catching stray dogs in inhumane way with metal pincers to People for Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) India. Subsequently, Peta raised a complaint with the AWBI in this regard.

“The issue of catching stray dogs in Dewas with metal tongs and their relocation was brought to our notice by some local activists. We are working on it. We are in touch with district administration, including DMC commissioner to stop the illegal activities,” said Peta in a statement.

Peta has also recommended for disciplinary action be taken against erring employees. It has instructed the DMC to train its staff on laws and guidelines for capturing dogs for Animal Birth Control programme.

DMC commissioner Sanjana Jain, however, claimed that all recommended guidelines and procedures were being followed by the civic body staff for sterilization work.

“People engaged in catching stray dogs with metal pincers are hired by locals when their kids are attacked by the animals. After care of stray dogs especially female ones is another issue with which we have to deal because locals do not allow our staff to leave a dog caught by us in the same area,” she said

Animal activists on contrary accused DMC of issuing false statement to mislead people. “DMC is just playing tricks by issuing misleading statement. The staff engaged in catching stray dogs with metallic pincers are using vehicles of the civic body,” alleged Roopa Patvardhan, one of the animal activists.

“The corporation’s staff also drop dogs back to their area after surgery,” she added.

Title: Consumer forum awards 2-yr jail to builder for contempt
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Nagpur: Delivering a rare verdict, the Additional District Consumer Disputes Redressal Forum awarded two years’ jail term to a builder for contempt of its order and also issued an arrest warrant against him. He managed to secure a temporary stay to the order from the state commission on a condition that he should pay entire amount as directed by the forum to complainant, who is a senior citizen.

While awarding stringent punishment to the Sunil Fating, proprietor of Pride Real Estate, a bench comprising president Shekhar Mule and members — Smita Chandekar and Avinash Prabhune — observed that the builder didn’t deserve any leniency for not executing forum’s orders of September 4, 2018, and also deliberately skipping judgment day hearing.

According to them, such stringent punishments are must for such elements which would act as deterrent. They also slapped Rs10,000 fine on the builder of which Rs5,000 is to be given to the complaint towards litigation cost.

In September 4, 2014’s order, the builder was directed to refund the complainant Pusha Sengraphwar’s Rs1.08 lakh taken for purchase of a plot from her from December 28, 2010 with 15% interest. He was also slapped with Rs25,000 fine towards physical and mental harassment along with litigation cost. He was given two options of either to refund complainant’s amount with 15% interest or as per current market value, whichever is higher. When he failed to comply with the order within 30 days deadline, the complainant filed execution (contempt) case.

Sengraphwar, a resident of Hudekeshwar, purchased a plot from Fating in 2010 by paying Rs1.08 lakh. When he failed to handover the property for many years, she filed a case in the forum. When he failed to respond to forum’s notices, a non-bailable warrant was issued against him after which the police produced him before the judges. He then admitted his mistake and paid Rs25,000 cost in July last year. He promised to pay remaining amount soon while citing excuses that one of his partners expired and other resigned and therefore, it would take time to remove their names from the property documents.

When he still failed to refund remaining amount, Sengraphwar filed contempt case in March 2018. The forum decided to pronounce verdict and conveyed to him to remain present. When he didn’t turn up, the judges awarded him two years imprisonment as per Section 27 of the Consumer Protection Act. They observed that the Fating not only failed to submit any document for his excuses, but also deliberately skipped the order date. Moreover, he didn’t file any appeal in higher court against forum’s first order of September 2018. He not only misled the forum, but also failed to engage any lawyer to plead his case. “If he’s disrespecting court’s orders, we can imagine how he should have behaved with the aggrieved complainant, who is a senior citizen,” the judges said.

Title: Maharashtra portfolio: Congress new demands delay distribution of portfolios in Maharashtra
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Maharashtra CM Uddhav Thackeray and NCP leader Ajit Pawar (L)

MUMBAI: A day after NCP leader and deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar said that portfolios would be declared on Thursday, no portfolios were announced following fresh demands raised by the Congress.

A senior NCP cabinet member told TOI that the Congress has asked for agriculture and industries or transport. “The Congress had earlier staked claim on urban development, agriculture and transport. Now it has dropped its claim on urban development but is still insisting on industries and transport,” he said.

The minister said delay in allotting portfolios was a major embarrassment for chief minister Uddhav Thackeray . “It has adversely affected the credibility of the Maha Vikas Aghadi government. First there was delay in swearing in of the chief minister, then further delay in cabinet expansion and now, no one in the government knows when the portfolios will be declared,” he said.

He said that initially, it was declared that portfolios would be announced on the day of the cabinet expansion but since that day, that is, December 30, there has been complete uncertainty over allotment of departments.

The NCP cabinet member said prima facie it appears that Congress is responsible for the delay. “Our information is that initially, there was an internal dispute in the Congress over allotment of portfolios. Both Ashok Chavan and Balasaheb Thorat had staked claim on the revenue department, while Nitin Raut had staked claim on the public works department. When Chavan found that he may not get revenue, he too had asked for PWD,” he said.

Both Thorat and Chavan did not respond on TOI queries on the delay in allotting portfolios.

Title: Hindustani dil as strong as ever
Content: AHMEDABAD: The cold inevitability of departure as well as the genius on which the sun never sets were both commemorated on the Saptak stage on Day 1 of its 2020 edition, on Wednesday. The eulogies for Pandit Ramakant Gundecha reminded the audience that though a cardiac arrest killed him at 56 in November last year, his art will be at the heart of music till music lives. And Pandit Jasraj , felicitated by Saptak on entering his 90th year, modestly suggested that vitality of art comes not from human perfection but from the blessings of a higher power.At that solemn moment, in the first night of the new year, the audience settled into the blanket of chill. They were reassured that immortality of art is not an abstraction; it is the faith in beauty which unites the performer and the listener.“The Dhrupad mission will go on,” Pandit Umakant Gundecha told TOI. “Pandit Ramakant Gundecha was ‘vadi swar’ — pure note. The work I undertook with him will be continued with his son, Anant.” Pandit Umakant and Anant Gundecha will perform on January 9 at Saptak.The imperishable force of beauty was also demonstrated by the Saptak custodian, Manju Mehta. Her Raga Tilak Shyam essay was praised by Pandit Jasraj. He said she had presented her guru Pandit Ravi Shankar’s oeuvre with felicity. “Pandit Ravi Shankar had created that raga,” Mehta told TOI. “His composition for ‘Jaane kaise sapnon mein kho gayee akhiyaan’ in the film ‘Anuradha’ is based on Tilak Shyam.” And Begum Parveen Sultana ’s Maru Bihag showed that Hindustani dil is as strong as ever.

Title: modi in Karnataka: Protest against Pakistan atrocities, not CAA: PM to Congress
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Prime Minister Narendra Modi (file photo)

TUMAKURU: PM Narendra Modi on Thursday lashed out at Congress and its allies for opposing the new citizenship law, saying they should explain why processions were being taken out against “Dalits and other religious minorities” seeking sanctuary in India while being “silent on Pakistan”, from where these refugees had fled “to save themselves and their daughters”.

Addressing students at the Sri Siddaganga Mutt in Tumakuru, 70km from Bengaluru, Modi said, “Those who have come to India are refugees from Pakistan since they were denied religious freedom there. Many Dalits and members of other minority communities there have been under constant attack. While we are trying to grant them citizenship, Congress has launched protests (against the move).”

The PM, who is on a two-day visit to Karnataka, said if Congress and its allies wanted to protest, their target should have been Pakistan. “Today, every Indian has a question: why are they (Congress and its allies) silent on Pakistan, which has committed atrocities on these people (refugees)?”

Modi accused Congress of keeping quiet for 70 years even as Pakistan “exploited members of the Dalit and other minority communities”.

“What prevented the party from raising the issue at an international level? If you (Congress) must raise slogans, then highlight the way minorities are tortured in Pakistan. If you must stage a procession, then support exploited Hindu minorities who have come to India from Pakistan,’’ Modi said in defence of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act.

“We can’t leave minorities from Pakistan to their fate. We have a responsibility to protect them. But Congress and its allies don’t speak against Pakistan; instead, they stage rallies against refugees and Parliament,’’ he added.

Congress immediately hit back at Modi, saying its anti-CAA agitation was against his “divisive policies and not against Parliament”.

“Modiji, this agitation is not against Parliament but against your divisive work. We will not let you break the country. So far as Pakistan is concerned, India taught them a lesson in 1948, 1965, 1971 and in Kargil, and inflicted so many wounds that they are not being able to cope with them. If you want to reply to Pakistan, stop playing games of biryani and mangoes,” the party said.

Former Karnataka CM Siddaramaiah criticised the PM for making a political speech in the presence of children “on the holy soil of the Siddaganga mutt”, which he described as “an apolitical, secular place”.

Title: Thunder showers and hail lash city, more rain expected today; temp set to drop next week again
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Nagpur: On the second day of the year, the city received around 20 millimetres less rain that it did in the entire month of June last year, which is when the monsoon season starts. Several parts of the city was also hit by hail.

Light to moderate rains are expected in some parts of the region on Friday.

On Wednesday-Thursday night, heavy showers began around 12.45am and continued in intervals till Thursday noon. According to the data of Regional Meteorological Centre, Nagpur, a total of 50mm rain was recorded in Nagpur between Wednesday midnight to 11.30am on Thursday.

In just three hours between 8.30-11.30am on Thursday, the city recorded 13.4mm rains, officials said.

Despite heavy rains that led to water logging in many areas, no records for the season were broke. Official data shows that the highest rainfall in the city for the month was 83mm recorded on January 1, 1985. Apart from this, the highest monthly total rains were recorded in 2005, when the city received a total of 129.3mm rains in January.

Many areas in the city reportedly received hailstorm too in the morning hours. Though the met department officially did not record information, photographs and videos of hailstorm from different areas went viral on social media.

TOI has been constantly reporting that the discontinuity in the flow of winds is bringing in moisture and rains in the region. “The flow of easterly and westerly winds is leading to rainfall in Central India,” the met officials said.

On December 27, the minimum temperature of Nagpur saw a drastic fall and went as low as 5.1 degree Celsius. However with the comeback of rains, the minimum temperature rose to 13.4 degrees Celsius on Wednesday.

While the minimum mercury level was 12.3 degrees Celsius on Thursday, the city’s maximum temperature of 18.4 degrees Celsius saw a drop of around 3-4 degrees compared to last one week. “As the weather is cloudy and sunlight is not much, the days are cooler with the maximum temperature seeing a fall. But in such weather conditions, the minimum temperature rises,” officials said.

According to RMC, light to moderate rains are expected in the region on Thursday following which sky would be clear. Minimum temperatures are likely to go down in the coming week.

Private weather agency Skymet has predicted chances of rainfall and cloudy sky for the next two days. “Light to moderate rain and thundershower with gusty winds will occur at some places over Kanker, Bhandara, Chandrapur, Gadchiroli, Gondiya, Latur, Nagpur, Nanded, Wardha and Yavatmal the districts of Vidarbha during next 6-8 hours,” stated its alert released on Thursday evening.

JUNE IN JANUARY

Total rains recorded between 12am to 11.30am | 50mm

Highest rainfall record for the month | 83mm on January 1, 1985

Highest total rainfall of the month | 129.3mm in 2005

Hailstorm reported in some areas

Flow of easterly and westerly winds is leading to rainfall in Central India

Moderate rains predicted for Friday, followed by clear sky for the week

Title: Hindutva right connotation for Hindus: RSS leader in book
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

NEW DELHI: Unfazed by criticism that it seeks creation of a “Hindu Rashtra”, RSS has asserted that “Hindutva” and not “Hinduism” is the right connotation for Hindus as “isms” indicated “rigid dogmas” and leave no space to evolve and accommodate contemporary changes in society.

J Nandkumar, national convenor of RSS think-tank “Prajna Pravah”, has authored a book “Hindutva in Changing Times”, where he justifies the “Hindutva” terminology. The book was released by senior RSS functionary Krishna Gopal here on Thursday. “It is Hindutva of India that keeps the whole country united,” Gopal said at the launch ceremony.

Nandakumar calls for reclaiming of West Bengal by a “nationalist government” and asserts the need to reinstate “democracy and constitutional supremacy”. The RSS functionary has alleged in the book that Mamata Bannerjee-led government in West Bengal has put restrictions on Hindu festivals in some areas with considerable Muslim presence to “appease Islamic radicals”.

In a chapter “Reclaiming Bengal”, Nandakumar goes on to allege that to ‘secularise’ the language, the Mamata government has removed all words from school textbooks which have a Hindu connection.

Sharing excerpts of the book, which has 25 chapters on subjects like “Hindutva and Democracy”, “Hindutva versus Nehruvian Secularism”, “Bharat’s True Destiny” and “The Dharma of Business”, Nandkumar told TOI, “I have made a humble attempt to analyse and see contemporary issues in the light of Hindutva paradigm.”

Kumar says certain “intellectuals” have problems with the term “Hindutva”, only because of an extraordinary hostility towards the faith. “Hindutva is nearest in meaning to Hinduness and it cannot be ‘Hinduism’. My contention is that ‘ism’ is a closed book of thought ... a rigid dogma,” he added. To explain “Hindutva”, the RSS functionary said, “Dr S Radhakrishnan defined Hinduism as not an end result but an open process. It is not a fixed revelation but an ever growing tradition, open to additions and adoptions, which is what I have analysed in the book.”

“The superficial similarity between Hindutva and Hinduism is responsible for this regrettable estrangement that, at times, alienates well-meaning people. The distinction between these two terms would be made clear...If there be really any word of alien growth, it is this word ‘Hindusim’,” Kumar starts the book quoting Hindutva icon Veer Savarkar’s “Essentials of Hindutva”.

Title: Hyderabad: Several booked for ‘violations’ during Million March
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Activist Medha Patkar along with Magasaysay award winner Sandeep Panday participating at a protest against CAA... Read More

HYDERABAD: The police has issued notices to the members of the anti-CAA joint action committee (JAC). Sleuths said that various police stations had issued notices to several youth under CrPC sections for allegedly violating the conditions of the police permission granted for the Million March on January 4.

Following the notices, police have started summoning those youths who have actively taken part in the Million March and whose names are said to be in more than twenty FIRs issued by various police stations across the city. In order to file charge-sheets in these cases, sleuths of Hyderabad police have started issuing notices to the accused under CRPC section 41(A).

In the FIRs, police alleged that Mushtaq Malik and his followers violated the conditions of joint commissioner of police (Central Zone) who had accorded permission for a protest on January 4 at Indira park Dharna Chowk. “Despite clear instructions of not permitting more than one thousand persons to take part in Million March, the followers of the JAC convenor took out rally by obstructing the free flow of traffic,” the FIR said.

To strengthen their position on the Miilion March cases, the names, vehicle numbers of those who had taken part in the march have been included in the FIRs. Even photographs and videos gathered by police during the march may be used as evidence when the accused are produced in court.

Alleging police harassment, a delegation of JAC on Thursday made a representation to the State Minorities Commission. “Police are exhibiting overzealous action...despite (the fact that the) march went on peacefully. They have booked several cases against youths and they are being summoned to the police station,” the JAC said in their statement.

Title: Rain catches city off guard, hits life, traffic
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Nagpur: Heavy unseasonal downpour accompanied with hail and chilly breeze on Thursday morning crippled normal life in many areas across the city.

Roads were flooded with knee-deep water and many areas reported streets carpeted with hail. Motorists found it difficult to wade through flooded streets. Waterlogging led to traffic snarls in many localities.

Mayor Sandip Joshi on Thursday visited City Operation Centre (COC) at NMC and took stock of the situation through CCTV cameras installed at various places in the city. The fire department also received complaints pertaining to rainwater entering many houses at Kapil Nagar in north Nagpur.

A tree was also uprooted in Mhalgi Nagar area. “The NMC’s fire department started the de-watering process in many areas,” said an official at NMC’s fire and emergency services control room.

Choked stormwater networks and overflowing nullahs spilled on to several major thoroughfares with knee-deep water, affecting vehicular traffic on many roads.

The busy Medical College road, Shatabdi Chowk to Beltarodi road and Dadiwala Layout in Jogi Nagar were affected due to rain.

Vehicles criss-crossing railway underbridges (RUBs) across the city faced hardships due to accumulated water on busy Narendra Nagar RUB, Mehdibagh RUB etc.

During his 10-minute stay at COC centre, Joshi observed water accumulation at Padole Square and he directed the officials from Laxmi Nagar zone and the fire department to de-water the busy square.

Traffic was affected in south, east and north Nagpur and there were heavy traffic jams on Narendra Nagar Ring Road due to waterlogging at the underbridge, traffic policemen told TOI.

Vehicular traffic passing through Mehdibagh RUB was also hit for almost two hours. It exposed the casual approach of the railway authorities to resolve waterlogging in this RUB, said local residents.

Title: Congress wing in MP distributes controversial Savarkar book
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

BHOPAL: Congress’s grassroots frontal organisation, Seva Dal, distributed controversial literature on Veer Savarkar in Bhopal on Wednesday even as RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat arrived in Indore to preside over a national meeting of the organisation.

A book titled “Veer Savarkar Kitne ‘Veer’?” was distributed among Seva Dal workers, who have gathered here from across the country for a 12-day training camp. Seva Dal national president Lalji Desai launched a scathing attack on RSS, calling it an “anti-national organization, since it does not respect either the country’s Constitution or the national flag”.

“When we distributed literature on Vinayak Damodar Savarkar , the intention was to tell our workers the truth about the freedom movement — that there is a huge difference between Congress’s patriotism and BJP’s ideology of polarising people. Our workers can, thereafter, take the message of Congress’s patriotism and sense of brotherhood to the common man,” Seva Dal state president Satyendra Yadav told TOI.

The literature distributed at the Seva Dal camp quotes books on Savarkar to call him “a person with communal mentality, which culminated in the Hindutva philosophy”. “During his last few years in jail, he (Savarkar) outlined his concept of Hindutva in the 1923 book ‘Essentials of Hindutva’, which in 1928 was re-printed as ‘Hindutva: Who is a Hindu?’ This ideology was meant to divide, which would divert attention of Hindus from the British and focus it on Muslims.” The book calls RSS a “communal organisation, loyal to the British”.

Title: Gadchiroli cops hold cleanliness drive under Raising Day programmes
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Cops cleaned premises of their police station, its surroundings and also public places

Nagpur: The Gadchiroli district police on Thursday kicked-off the State Police Raising Day programmes with a cleanliness drive. The programmes, planned between January 2 and 8, will be organized at different places across the district.

Under the cleanliness drive titled ‘Swachha Bharat-Swachha police’, cops took up brooms and spades to clean premises of their police station, its surroundings and also public places. Police volunteered by performing labour, identified as ‘Shram daan’, for the cleanliness drive.

On Friday, cops would visit schools and other educational institutions to observe the birth anniversary of Savitribai Phule. The cops would create awareness about ‘women safety’ at girls’ schools, high schools and colleges.

Police have also taken up the plan to prepare and distribute caste certificates among the local residents under ‘Project Pragati’. The cops would also organize awareness rally and musical shows of police bands at prominent places at Gadchiroli and Aheri.

Initiatives will be taken to return the recovered properties of victims with due legal procedures.

Title: Lucknow lawyers refuse to appear for ‘anti-nationals’
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

LUCKNOW: Septuagenarian Haseena has been making rounds of the courts here for a week now to find a lawyer for her grandson Waseem, 27, arrested for his alleged involvement in violence during protests against CAA on December 19, but hasn’t been able to find anybody willing to take up the case.

“My neighbours helped me approach some lawyers in the lower courts, but they refused to take up my case. They called Waseem anti-national and ridiculed me,” said Haseena, a resident of Old Basmandi.

Like Haseena, many others are finding it tough to get lawyers to file bail applications for their arrested kin. Several families claimed lawyers had turned down their requests, saying that their kin indulged in “anti-national activity”.

Title: Gadchiroli police, NGO distribute stationery items among students
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

The programme was organized by Yerkad Armed Outpost in the Maoist-sensitive remote Japtalai hamlet

Nagpur: Gadchiroli police, in collaboration with non-governmental organization (NGO) Akansha Bahuddeshiya Sanstha, Parbhani, distributed stationery material among 65 students of Zilla Parishad school, Japtalai, this week. The programme was organized by Yerkad Armed Outpost in the Maoist-sensitive remote Japtalai hamlet.

The programme was aimed bringing children closer to education and school. The main theme was school education and its significance. In Maoists-affected regions, the rebels have been trying to wean away the students community from education and appealing them to join the armed movement against the government.

The students welcomed the guests with the traditional tribal dance and other programmes. The teachers, students and their parents, along with the police, extended their gratitude for organizing an education centric programme.

On Friday, the police will organize a carnival for youngsters at Gadchiroli police complex. It would have several attractions for youngsters, including games and food stalls.

The programmes are being conducted under the supervision of SP Shailesh Balkawade, addl SPs Mohit Kumar Garg and Ajay Kumar Bansal and sub-divisional police officer Vikrant Gaikwad.

Title: India briefed all foreign govts on CAA, NRC: MEA
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

MEA spokesperson Raveesh Kumar

NEW DELHI: Denying reports that there had been no foreign outreach on CAA and NRC , the government said Thursday Indian diplomats had briefed all foreign capitals on both issues. On NRC, according to MEA , the government has said that it’s a process mandated by the Supreme Court and that it should be seen as separate from CAA.

“We emphasised that CAA just expedites acquiring of citizenship to persecuted minorities. It does not change basic structure of the Constitution,” MEA spokesperson Raveesh Kumar said at a media briefing.

He said that Indian missions had been asked to convey to the local governments that the Act provides expedited consideration for Indian citizenship to persecuted minorities. Without mentioning Muslims, even other citizens, he said, had “existing avenues’’ to explore for citizenship.

The spokesperson said it was wrong to claim that diplomats were upset with the citizenship law.

Title: No leopard, yet Metro ‘shuts’ Little Wood for walkers
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Nagpur: Even as there is no direct or indirect evidence of leopard presence in Ambazari reserve forest , the MahaMetro has shut the door on morning walkers at Little Wood , the forest land in its possession.

Hundreds of nature lovers and morning walkers residing on Hingna Road visit the Little Wood daily to exercise and walk on the 3.5km nature trail. The nature trail is closed since December 7 after a labourer sighted a leopard in the forest.

Presence of a leopard in the biodiversity park with indirect evidence like pug marks was first reported by visitors on November 28. The park was closed for visitors from November 29.

On December 6, forest department found direct evidence of the leopard with a wild boar kill. Since then the park remained closed till December 18. As no further evidence was found, the biodiversity park was reopened from December 19.

Even as forest department, which has more responsibility towards visitors visiting the park, has opened the area, MahaMetro has not removed the board on its gate that states that the park is closed due to leopard presence the area.

MahaMetro spokesperson Akhilesh Halve said, “Though a notice of caution has been displayed at the gate, we have officially not closed Little Wood and people are being allowed.” But visitors complained they were being turned down by the guards.

P Kalyan Kumar, chief conservator of forests (CCF), Nagpur, said, “We have scanned the entire forest area and there is no evidence of leopard as of now. There is no point in avoiding morning walkers. We need to connect with the communities to sensitize them about nature.”

Title: Hyderabad preferred destination for multi-crore education deals
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Home to a string of international schools, Hyderabad is fast becoming India’s preferred destination for mega multi-crore investments in education. Between 2018 and 2019, three of the top four marquee deals signed in the country, came Hyderabad’s way – the ticket size ranging anywhere between Rs 700 crore and Rs 2,000 crore. Collectively, India saw about $1 billion being pumped into its education sector last year, say highly-placed industry sources.This trend of private equity (PE) investments in schools is expected to continue through 2020 with analysts predicting another $1 billion coming India’s way. In fact, many say the country’s educational sector has the potential to attract up to $4-5 billion.Up for grabs in 2020 are at least three large school chains from Hyderabad, Mumbai and Chennai apart from several smaller institutions across the country. “While 2019 was about a few big deals, 2020 will see at least half a dozen small deals worth Rs 250 crore to Rs 500 crore,” said an investor, attributing this sudden rush of PE funds to the landmark KKR-EuroKids deal, signed in August last year.Global PE giant KKR acquired the preschool chain, EuroKids, reportedly for Rs 2,000 crore, making for the biggest headlines in the K-12 (kindergarten to class 12) sector. Many heads turned even when Hong Kong-based Nord Anglia Education acquired one of Hyderabad’s most prominent private school chains, Oakridge International Schools, in February. The deal was closed for Rs 1,600 crore. Later in November, another major investment was reported from the city when Cognita, a private schools group headquartered in Finland, made a foray into India with Chirec International, for a supposed Rs 700 crore.While news of Sri Chaitanya Schools, another major Hyderabad-based player in the K-12 sector, being bought by PE investors Brookfield and Kalpathi Investments did the rounds in October, sources say, the parties are yet to sign on the dotted line.Once done, it could well stand out as the biggest transaction in India, so far.Earlier in 2018, Chaitanya’s competitor Narayana attracted about Rs 500 crore from Morgan Stanley’s PE arm, Banyan Tree Capital.But what’s driving this trend? Experts attribute it to India’s large private school-going populace which, at 150 million, is the highest in the world. “Rapid urbanisation coupled with the largest school going population in the world will ensure that the education sector continues to be interesting for global investors,” said Jasmeet Chhabra, managing partner of Cerestra, a leading edu-infra firm. He added: “Given the large base of professional workforce in cities like Hyderabad, it would be safe to say that bulk of this interest will be centered here and in other cities like Bengaluru and Pune.” The firm has investments to the tune of Rs 1,200 crore across all major metros and is expected to double its portfolio in 2020.Allaying fears of parents about this trend making quality private education a fiefdom of the rich, experts said that it will, on the contrary, improve standards across the sector.“As has been the case so far, there will not be any hike in school fee. What we can expect are: better quality of teachers because of improved salaries and more school chains that follow standardised practices,” said a source privy to some big deals brokered in 2019.The source added: “The practice that has started from Hyderabad will gradually move into all big cities, and some tier 2 cities too over the next few years.”

Title: Amitabh Bachchan reveals what to call a 'Selfie' in Hindi
Content:
T 3599 - .. at times it is worth the while to look into the mirror .. a selfie of the self .. SELFIE hindi versio… https://t.co/hPtg5EISz3 — Amitabh Bachchan (@SrBachchan) 1577993671000

Megastar Amitabh Bachchan is quite active on social media. He keeps his fans updated with his regular posts on Twitter.
