Title: Fadnavis slams govt, seeks relief for hail-hit farmers
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Nagpur: Devendra Fadnavis, leader of opposition in the state assembly, on Thursday demanded relief for hailstorm-hit farmers of the district. According to him, hail has damaged crops in large areas.

Addressing public meetings at Amdi Phata and Dhanala villages in view of zilla parishad (ZP) elections, the former chief minister said, “The Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government has started its innings by betraying the farmers. Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray had demanded compensation of Rs 25,000 per hectare for farmers whose crops had been damaged due to unseasonal rains in October.”

“Leaders of Congress and NCP had demanded Rs 50,000 per hectare. However, after coming to power, the government did not increase the relief beyond that granted by the governor,” he said.

Turning to crop loan waiver scheme of the state government, he said, “Our government had waived loans taken between 2001 and 2017. MVA has waived loans taken after that, which means only a period of two years has been considered. They have put the cut-off date at September 2019 so that farmers who had taken loans in October 2019 due to crop damage do not get any benefit. MVA leaders had promised to waive off entire crop loan but now they have inserted a condition that farmers whose loan exceeds Rs 2 lakh will not be eligible for waiver. The government is anti-farmer.”

Slamming Shiv Sena, Congress and NCP leaders for squabbling over portfolios, Fadnavis said, “The ministers are lobbying for ‘plum’ portfolios but nobody wants agriculture. This shows how their love for farmers is not sincere.”

Recounting the steps taken by the BJP government for farmers, he said they beneftted greatly from Shetkari Sanman Nidhi. “Former energy minister Chandrashekhar Bawankule had sanctioned a large number of agricultural pump connections but did not disconnect even a single farmer for non-payment of bills. Our government worked for long-term upliftment of farmers.”

The BJP neta also held a meeting of party workers at Amdi Phata and Dhanala. He then attended the inauguration of new campus of National Fire Service College at hands of Union home minister Amit Shah. In the evening, he addressed a public meeting at Digdoh and held a party meeting. His public meeting at Besa was cancelled due to some reason.

Title: Ryots staring at fresh crop losses due to unseasonal rain
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Nagpur: Unseasonal rain at the beginning of new year is expected to bring another bout of losses for farmers. Even as confirmed reports are yet to reach, the agriculture department is compiling data from its field-level offices throughout the region.

Cotton, a kharif crop and the mainstay of Vidarbha’s farmers that has still not been entirely harvested, is expected to be hit. Rabi crops like chana (gram) and wheat, which are in germination stage at present, are also likely to be affected with losses to orange growers not being ruled out too.

Officials from the agriculture department said that it may be too early to predict the extent of losses. Some of the farmers TOI spoke to also ruled out of losses being severe at this stage but there were conflicting versions too.

The region’s kharif crops that are harvested between October to January include cotton, soyabean, tur and paddy. Even as soyabean has been harvested, one more round of picking remains for cotton. The remaining bolls are expected to be hit due to the rains, especially if there has been a hailstorm in the area, said a source in the state’s agriculture department.

The rabi crops that are harvested in March are chana and wheat, said sources. The crops may be damaged if the rain water remains stagnated in the fields.

Paddy that has been left in the fields after harvest may be damaged too, thus bringing down its prices. Vishal Barbate, a paddy grower at Ramtek, said that some of the farmers may have still left the paddy crop in the farms to dry. The stacking is done after the crop is dried.

Tur that is harvested in this month is likely to be the most vulnerable. Gajanan Singawar from Yavatmal said that even as he has entirely harvested soyabean, tur remains in the farms. “The crops that are in flowering stage are likely to be completely damaged due to the rains,” he said.

Title: Kota deaths: Yogi & Maya attack Sonia & Priyanka
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Family members and relatives of their infant children wait outside the JK Lone hospital, Kota (PTI)

NEW DELHI: Congress president Sonia Gandhi on Thursday expressed concern over infant deaths in a Kota hospital in Rajasthan as political sparring mounted over the issue and rivals accused the opposition party of maintaining silence over the development in the party-ruled state. Over 100 infants died in December in JK Lon hospital.

Sonia Gandhi summoned AICC general secretary in-charge of Rajasthan Avinash Pande for a discussion on Thursday. “She wanted to know the reasons of the deaths. It is a very sad situation and the CM has been asked to act on the report. The BJP allegation (of Congress government’s insensitivity) is untrue as the inquiry is on and those responsible will be punished,” Pande said after meeting Sonia.

In a series of tweets, Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath said, “The death of 100 innocent children is extremely saddening and heart-wrenching. It is extremely sad that Congress president Sonia Gandhi and general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, despite being women, are not able to understand the sorrow of the mothers.”

He added it would have been better “had Priyanka met and consoled the aggrieved mothers instead of indulging in politics in UP”. Priyanka was recently on a tour to UP where she attacked BJP and the UP government over the Citizenship Amendment Act and police firing during protests, and also visited relatives of the victims.

Calling CM Ashok Gehlot as “insensitive, disinterested and irresponsible”, Mayawati said, “But, what is more saddening is the fact that the top leadership of Congress, especially its general secretary, are maintaining silence over this issue. It would have been better that like she did in UP, she had met the aggrieved mothers, who lost their children due to the laxity of the party’s government.”

“There should be no politics over the issue. Infant mortality at this hospital is steadily decreasing,” said Gehlot.

Title: States eye fresh harvest, cold to imported onions
Content:
File photo

As per target fixed, consignments of imported onion have started arriving from 15 December onwards and approx 42500… https://t.co/rczahKkqoi — Ram Vilas Paswan (@irvpaswan) 1577713870000

NEW DELHI: In less than a month, the government is staring at problem of plenty as states appear reluctant to lift imported onions with the arrival of a fresh crop beginning to cool prices. On Thursday, the onion price in Lasalgaon, the country’s largest wholesale onion market, was Rs 3,500 per quintal as against a record-high of Rs 8,600 last month.The high prices across most cities might wane with arrival of more kharif crops in mandis. The fresh harvest would not only moderate prices but also seems to be reducing states’ interest to lift imported onion from the central buffer. The Centre has contracted import of about 45,000 tonnes, of which over 5,000 tonnes have already arrived. Though there was a plan to import one lakh tonnes of the kitchen staple, it has been put on hold. “First we have to dispose of the quantity that has arrived and shipment that are on the way. Some states are taking imported onion, but that’s much less than what they had indicated to check prices,” said an official.The concern is also evident from a recent tweet by consumer affairs minister Ram Vilas Paswan . “As per target fixed, consignments of imported onion have started arriving from December 15 onwards and approx 42,500 tonnes of onion stock is available. I request state governments to send their demand to department of consumer affairs and NAFED to augment onion supply,” he tweeted.Sources said that even in the retail market there are few takers of imported onions as it lacks the pungency or taste Indian consumers like. The government is now planning to increase the buffer stock of domestic onion this year.TOI has learnt that the issue of states lifting less imported onion was also discussed in a meeting of Group of Ministers headed by home minister Amit Shah .Officials said that the states will have to help dispose of the onion stock to avoid “losses” as the perishable item cannot be stored for long. Earlier, the government had said that there was about 50% “loss” to the 57,000 tonnes of onion it had stored this year after procuring directly from farmers.Sources said the abnormal price in the past couple of months was due to short supply and delay in arrival of fresh crop and effect of flooding in some parts, which triggered the need to import. But the situation is improving very quickly as arrival of fresh crop has picked up. “There is significant price correction across markets. The situation will improve and prices in retail market will fall soon,” said an official.

Title: DMK ahead of ruling ADMK in rural body polls
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

CHENNAI: The rural local body elections in Tamil Nadu , held after a gap of eight years, the first after the demise of M Karunanidhi and J Jayalalithaa , have turned out to be in favour of DMK as the party registered big wins across the state. The results, declared till Thursday night, indicated a setback for the governing AIADMK.

While DMK held a clear lead in the morning, AIADMK caught up and managed to surge ahead in several places later. Towards the end of the day, when counting was still incomplete in many places, DMK managed to retain more number of district councillor posts as well as panchayat union councillor posts. It was a close contest and AIADMK was not far behind. The results are likely to be officially declared on Friday.

The day was marked by complaints from opposition parties as well as government staff deployed for poll duty. At a counting centre at Dharmapuri , DMK cadres complained that CCTV cameras were not functioning. In Karur, they objected to the alleged presence of AIADMK men at counting centres. The government staff, meanwhile, complained of delay in providing food to them. CM Edappadi K Palaniswami went into a huddle with party functionaries as the results showed DMK ahead. DMK president M K Stalin, on the other hand, upped the ante and complained to the SEC, alleging that the party in government was scheming to scuttle DMK’s victory with the help of officials.

Celebrations broke out as the results started to come in, spreading cheer in the DMK camp. Poll watchers did not rule out a change in the trend by Friday. Ceding of so many seats to the opposition party, however, is seen as a blow to AIADMK. “It is a definite setback for AIADMK, which is known for its rural vote bank,” said political analyst Tharasu Shyam.

Title: Delhi Factory Fire: Firefighter dies battling blaze in battery factory, 17 rescued
Content:
Amit Balyan and two colleagues were trapped under debris when the building collapsed.

Balyan with his wife Shivani, a UP police constable. The two had got married last February.

Fireman goes down fighting as blaze spirals out of control after explosions

Building was more than 40 years old, stuffed with batteries, chemicals and plastic

NEW DELHI: One fireman died while 14 others had a narrow escape when a part of the factory-cum-outlet of a wellknown battery manufacturing firm where they were battling a major blaze collapsed following a series of sudden explosions in west Delhi’s Peeragarhi on Thursday.Fireman Amit Balyan, who had joined the department last year and got married recently, was buried under a pile of debris following the explosions triggered by a compressor burst. He died due to excessive bleeding and smoke inhalation. It took firemen five hours to pull his body out of the debris.The fire, which started at the basement around 4am, was brought under control after an intense, 12-hour-long operation. Firemen said the blaze had initially been controlled but suddenly the compressor unit, used to fill acid in the batteries, exploded in the basement. This caused a chain of blasts in batteries at the factories due to which the rear portion of the building capsized on the firemen who were dousing the flames.Balyan’s father, Babu Ram, is an assistant sub-inspector with Delhi Police. His wife, Shivani, is a UP police constable posted in Ghaziabad. They had married in February last year after a brief love affair.Balyan, along with his colleagues Mahavir and Manjeet Rana, was buried under the debris after the blasts while 12 other firemen and three caretakers of the factory were either hit by falling concrete slabs or had lucky escapes as the slab fell around them. One of the caretakers, Brijender Kashyap, had to be admitted to the hospital for treatment.The fire department rushed seven fire tenders to douse the flames. However, as the fire got out of control after the explosions, 69 fire tenders along with 500 firemen were pressed into the service. Three of the firemen including Balyan were completely buried under the concrete while the rest suffered injuries in the 3,000-sq-foot basement. Firemen say that the factory was stuffed with batteries and chemicals that made their rescue operation tedious and risky.The building is located at Udyog Nagar Industrial Area of Peeragarhi. Fire officials said they could reach the scene within minutes as the factory is located just a stone’s throw away from the area fire station. “The whole structure of the building had weakened and it started collapsing. We could not use cranes for the rescue operation as the building would have collapsed further, causing more injuries. We had to remove the debris using our hands. The fire-fighting operation too had to be conducted in tandem,” said Atul Garg, Director, DFS.The fire department informed the NDRF about the incident who had to cut open the concrete to rescue the trapped firemen.Fire officials said the building was more than 40 years old and was stuffed with chemicals and plastic emitting toxic fumes, which made fire-fighting operation difficult. It was found that the building neither had an NOC from the fire department nor had any fire-fighting equipment installed.Munna Lal, a worker at a factory behind the building, said, “I came for work around 8.30am and the flames could be seen coming through the grills. The firemen were trying to douse the flames and suddenly there were three blasts. Even our building shook when it happened. There was dust and smoke all around and we could hear people scream about firemen and a worker getting stuck under the debris.”Fire officers say that their major challenge was to rescue Balyan who was stuck under the heaviest pile of debris. Initially the fire officials could see his hand and even tried to send oxygen supply to him. However, the heat and the heavy concrete slabs which had to be moved with hands made it difficult. Balyan was pulled out by 2.15pm and was declared “brought dead” at the hospital.Investigations have revealed that the factory was registered in the name of Anil Gupta. “We have registered a case of causing death due to negligence with respect to fire or combustible matter, causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others and death due to negligence,” a police officer said. Police are probing whether the owners had the permission to store such large amount of acid and combustible material.Fire officials say that the blaze was completely doused around 6pm but cooling operations went on till late at night as the fire fighters had to be cautious about the building collapsing again.BJP MP Manoj Tiwari and health minister Satyendar Jain visited the spot to take account of the situation. LG Baijal also visited the hospital to meet the injured.

Title: This video of Aayush Sharma's son Ahil talking about his New Year's plans is the cutest thing you will come across today!
Content: Salman Khan's sister Arpita Khan Sharma and actor Aayush Sharma 's son Ahil's pictures and videos take over the internet in no time. The superstar and the couple's Instagram feed is proof that Ahil is the apple of their eyes. And now, Arpita and Aayush welcomed their second child, a baby girl, on Salman Khan 's 54th birthday.Salman's brother-in-law and producer, Atul Agnihotri took to his Instagram to share a video of Ahil where he talks about his New Year's plans. In the video, he reveals that his plan is to take a picture, work out and more. Atul captioned the post, "Ahil’s New Year plans 😍 @arpitakhansharma @aaysharma"Check out the video here:Hours after Aayush and Arpita's birth, the proud parents took to social media to announce that they have named their little bundle of joy, Ayat Sharma.In an official statement, Arpita and Ayush had expressed, “With great joy and immense pleasure, we announce that we have been blessed with a baby girl. On this joyous occasion, we would like to thank our family, friends and all our well-wishers for their unconditional support. We also extended a humble thank you to our media friends and to our fans for their constant love and support. This journey couldn’t have been complete without you all."

Title: Seizures worth crores of rupees at IGI airport on New Year’s day
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

The seized gold bars have an estimated value of Rs 1.4 crore.

NEW DELHI: On the first day of 2020, customs officials at Indira Gandhi International (IGI) airport made seizures worth over a few crores in six different cases. As many as 11 people were arrested.

The biggest catch was that of gold bars weighing 4 kg, which has an estimated value of up to Rs 1.4 crore. The gold, to the officials’ surprise, was lying unclaimed under the passenger seat of a flight coming from Muscat.

In another case, customs officials seized red sanders weighing 127 kg and valued at Rs 12.70 lakh from three passengers who were planning to depart to Hong Kong. All three men were arrested.

On Wednesday itself, another man was caught with seven gold bars weighing 2.6 kg, which was valued at Rs 88 lakh. He had arrived from Bahrain and was arrested after he admitted that he had also smuggled gold worth over Rs 2 crore in the past.

In the fourth case, four Afghani men were caught with four gold chains weighing 1,499 grams. They had come from Sharjah with gold worth over Rs 50 lakh. Upon their arrest, they said that they had been involved in smuggling gold into Delhi in the past.

In the last seizure of the day, officials seized two cylindrical pieces of gold weighing 646 grams worth Rs 22 lakh from a mother-son duo. They had come to Delhi from Bangkok. They have been arrested. The duo have also confessed to their prior involvement in smuggling cases over the past few months, the officials said.

In the last incident of the day, the team seized a gold chain weighing 969 grams valued at Rs 33 lakh from a Turkmenistan woman. She admitted to having smuggled gold during her past visits as well.

Title: Delhiites spent Rs 1,000 crore on liquor last December
Content:
December brought some good fortune for the liquor industry, with Delhiites gulping down alcohol worth almost R... Read More

NEW DELHI: December brought some good fortune for the liquor industry, with Delhiites gulping down alcohol worth almost Rs 1,000 crore, sources said.While the actual data on the number of bottles sold through vends and hotels and bars during the month is still being compiled, a source said the amount had been calculated on the basis of the revenue the excise department earned as duty paid on liquor bottles.According to sources, the excise department earned Rs 465 crore as duty on liquor in the month of December in comparison with Rs 460 crore earned in the last month of 2018, showing an insignificant increase of just about 1%.“This amount is calculated on the basis of liquor supplied to the vends, hotels and bars,” said an excise department official, requesting anonymity.Delhi has a network of 864 liquor vends — government-run and private — while 951 hotels, bars and clubs have the licence to serve alcohol to customers.Interestingly, Delhi witnessed a record sale of liquor in December 2019, which was the second-coldest month ever since 1901.Sources said the excise department’s decision to slash the prices of a few popular brands of imported liquor contributed the increase in its earnings. The excise department in November last reduced prices of about 10 brands of foreign liquor by 20-25%.“The sale of these brands witnessed a surge of about three times after the prices were revised. Earlier, people used to buy foreign liquor from neighbouring Haryana due to a price difference of Rs800-1200 per bottle and smuggle it to Delhi. With reduced prices, the difference in the rate is not much, which made Delhi customers buy these brands locally,” said an official.Another source said that the department’s earnings would have been even more, had the government not shut down 120 departmental store that sold wine and beer in the third week of December after complaints of irregularities.In Video: Delhiites spent Rs 1,000 crore on liquor last December

Title: It was Rajasekhar vs Chiranjeevi at MAA diary launch
Content: High drama ensued at the launch of the annual diary of the Movie Artistes Association. The event witnessed a fiery war of words between Megastar Chiranjeevi and MAA Vice President Rajasekhar over problems that exist within the association. It all started when Chiru spoke about how all members of the association must work together as one family and sort out all issues between them. An irked Rajasekhar immediately took the mic and went on a rant about how there’s an attempt to showcase the industry as one big, happy family when all is not well in the association.“Ever since I took over as Vice-President of MAA, I’ve been tirelessly working towards the progress of the association and the artistes. So much so that I have not even done a single film since. Chiranjeevi says we should sort things out as one family and move forward. However, when you light a fire, you cannot expect smoke to not be there. Every family will have problems but you can’t pretend we’re all happy to the outside world. What’s wrong in accepting that there are problems? We act like heroes on screen, but when someone is trying to act like a hero in real life, their voices are being throttled. What kind of industry is this?”, Rajasekhar fumed.An infuriated Chiru slammed Rajasekhar for his behaviour and called for disciplinary action to be taken against him. “If you have something nice to say, please say it out loud. If not, have a meaningful discussion. When there are elders, one must speak with respect. Why should all of us stay here and be humiliated like this? How embarrassing is it for someone to show the industry in a bad light to the outside world?,” asked an enraged Chiru. “I strongly condemn his actions. When all of us were partaking in a sensible discussion, to aggressively snatch a mic, without following protocol or showing any respect to others is despicable. I don’t understand such behaviour,” he added. Veteran actor and former MAA President Mohan Babu also sparred with Rajasekhar, but was told to calm to down by Chiranjeevi. In fact, Chiru and Mohan Babu displayed a never-seen-before bonhomie on stage with the Sye Raa star even planting a kiss on Mohan Babu’s cheek. Interesting, indeed!

Title: This GAY couple wore the most beautiful sherwanis for their Spanish wedding
Content: When it comes to celebrating love, no one does it better than couples who belong to the LGBT community. Not only does it take them a lot of courage to come out of the closet but it takes a different sort of power to take the next step. And, for gay couples, this strong step is attained when they decide to tie the knot in presence of their loved ones. We came across one such couple on Instagram, thanks to ace designer Sabyasachi Mukherjee, who took to Instagram to share the wedding photos of his handsome clients.Sabysachi shared the lovely wedding pictures of Romit Deb and Walter Badillo, who tied the knot in the beautiful capital of Spain’s Andalusia region, Seville. Interestingly, the couple tied the knot five-years-ago, but the pictures are setting the internet on fire now, after Sabyasachi shared them with the world.The handsome couple donned beautiful Sabyasachi creations for their big day. While Romit donned a classic black sherwani with gold buttons from the House of Sabyasachi, Walter opted for an embroidered creation in black and gold.Romit finished off the look with a graceful shawl stole, white churidar and black shoes, Walter completed his look with an off white churidar and black shoes.This is not the first time the ace couturier has dressed a gay or lesbian couple, the famous designer is a favourite when it comes to desi boys and girls settled abroad. And hey, we are not complaining as we get to see such gorgeous looking couples on Instagram, all the time.We loved Romit and Walter's wedding outfits, tell us how did you like them in the comment section below.Photo: Niccolo Guasti

Title: Delhi looking skyward to solve its parking puzzle
Content:
Delhi’s first tower parking at Green Park

NEW DELHI: The city got its first tower parking on Thursday when Union urban affairs minister Hardeep Puri inaugurated the modern facility on Aurobindo Marg at Green Park . The 17-storey prefabricated steel structure with automated vehicle placement lifts is touted as the model solution to the parking woes in the spacestarved capital. Puri confirmed this when he remarked, “The public-private partnership model, with the government providing gap viability funds, can be the way forward. My ministry will provide full support to such projects.”While only two 39.5-metre towers were inaugurated on Thursday, SDMC commissioner Gyanesh Bharti assured that all four towers would become operational within a month. There would be added facilities like toilets, baby sitting room and waiting rooms for drivers.The foundation stone of the parking was laid in March last year. Mayor Sunita Kangra said that despite financial crunch in SDMC, it was able to execute the project in nine months. “Inaugurating these two towers is an achievement, given shortages in our budget,” Kangra said.Delhi has more than 75 lakh active vehicles, but the municipal corporations have space to accommodate just 94,000 vehicles in 434 surface, stack and multilevel parking facilities. That is why optimum use of space was so important. The Green Park facility offers fully automated parking within a small space of 236 sq metres. The structure can hold 136 vehicles in the four towers. While the first to fourth floors have been designed to park 32 SUVs or big vehicles, the fifth to seventeenth floors can hold 104 sedans, an SDMC official said.The two towers now operational have space for 68 cars. “Tower parking requires a 1.5-sq metre space to park a car compared with 30 sq m necessary in conventional parking,” explained Bharti. He said that four other automated parking lots are being developed in south Delhi. While those at Adhchini and Lajpat Nagar will be completed in another four months, bids have been invited for similar structures at New Friends Colony and Nizamuddin. Some residents have, however, expressed concern that high-rise steel structures like these would affect the aesthetics of the capital’s skyline.Lieutenant governor Anil Baijal, present at the inauguration, said that when he assumed office, he realised parking and traffic management were among the biggest problems faced by Delhi. “These prefabricated parking lots are easier to set up as well as more user friendly than the brick-mortar parkings,” Baijal said. He asked SDMC and the traffic police to ensure that all roadside parking was now curbed. “When traffic flow is smooth, the pollution level also goes down,” he added.According to an SDMC official, a car would first be parked on the robotic arm by an attendant. Capable of 360-degree swivelling, the arm would pick up the vehicle and place it on a platform to be taken up by a lift to an empty slot on any of the 17 floors. It can be recalled by pressing the car number on the input screen on the ground floor. The retrieval time for a vehicle will be three minutes.

Title: Delhi Fire: Unstable building, toxic fumes made rescue operations tough
Content:
Rescuing the 14 firemen trapped in debris was one of the most challenging operations for Delhi Fire Service an... Read More

NEW DELHI: Rescuing the 14 firemen trapped in debris was one of the most challenging operations for Delhi Fire Service and National Disaster Response Force (NDRF). Not only was there a fear of inhaling harmful acid fumes, but the building had also become extremely unstable. A complete collapse would have led to further loss of life.The rescuers adopted the three-pronged approach of extinguishing, cutting and rescuing the trapped firemen at the same time. Parts of the building collapsed thrice during the firefighting that had been on since morning.When the firemen reached the building located in D-Block of Udyog Nagar and started dousing the blaze, little did they know that parts of it would soon collapse on them.Sanjay Tomar, deputy chief fire officer, said, “The firemen were standing in the circulating space. A compressor in the basement blasted and debris fell on the firefighters. While some men in the basement were rescued safely, those on the sides were stuck by debris. The leg of Mahavir, one of the firemen, got stuck under the debris, but we managed to pull him out.”The firefighters said that the biggest challenge for them was lack of space. The building was located at the edge of a drain, which didn’t give the firemen enough space to bring in an earthmover. Moreover, the molten batteries kept in the basement had turned into a pool of burning plastic and chemicals and were emitting toxic smoke.“The firemen trapped under the debris and the ones rescuing them had to be supplied with fresh air otherwise they would have fallen unconscious,” said a fire officer.Officials said they had to break down one of the walls of an adjacent building using an earthmover to gain access to the portion that had collapsed. Firemen wove the end of a rope into a chair-like shape to lift out the injured. To ensure that there were no further injuries to the rescuers, grilles and ladders were used to enter the premises from the adjoining buildings.Senior officers present at the spot said another major challenge faced by them was raw acid flowing out of the storage area. “We had to ensure that our suits didn’t get burnt by the chemical. We had to work slowly into the building spraying foam and water,” said a fire officer.To gain access to the building, the firemen used lifts to reach the facade and break open the glass panes. This allowed the toxic fumes to leave the building and gave access to the hosepipes of the fire tenders. An inquiry is being conducted to find out whether there were any violations in the construction of the building as there was little space left for manoeuvring.In Video: One firefighter dead, several injured in Delhi's Peeragarhi fire

Title: Bhandup school caretaker held in Rs 3.5 crore fraud case
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Police on Wednesday arrested the caretaker of a private educational institution who, along with a few others, allegedly fabricated documents and forged signatures of the owner and transferred his property worth Rs 3.5 crore.

The Economic Offences Wing seized fabricated documents from Ashok Kumar Singh, 52. Police said they were looking for his accomplices. The nearly two-acre property owned by Johnson Iruddhaya is at Rajdeep Nagar Society in Bhandup (W). Police said Iruddhaya set up Bhandup Village Citizen Education Society and got it registered with the charity commissioner. In 2012, he started a school, Mary John English School, for the underprivileged. Iruddhaya later shifted to Chennai and appointed Singh as caretaker.

“Recently, the complainant learnt Singh had submitted bogus documents before the charity commissioner, forged his signature and declared him the trustee of both the Bhandup Village Citizen Education Society and Mary John English School and transferred the property in his name,” said an officer. Police carried out a search of Singh’s house and found documents pertaining to the property.

Title: Mumbai: Woman jumps to death from building terrace, passerby dislocates arm in bid to save her
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Passersby noticed the woman trying to climb on to the terrace parapet of the eight-storey building in Kandivli... Read More

MUMBAI: A 40-year-old woman, who was reportedly depressed after losing her job, jumped to her death from the terrace of an eight-storey building in Kandivli (west) on Thursday evening. A passerby tried to catch her and ended up dislocating his arm.

The woman, Dimple Wadilal, stayed with her mother and brother in Rock Avenue building on the eighth floor.

The incident occurred around 5.30pm when Dimple walked to the terrace and climbed on to the the parapet. Passersby noticed her and asked her to step back. Charkop police probing the case said a man dislocated his shoulder while trying to catch her.

Police said Wadilal worked in a private firm. Her brother is a cabin crew with a private airline and is currently out of the country. “We are not sure if she has left a suicide note. The mother told us that she was depressed,’’ said Charkop police senior inspector Vitthal Shinde.

The woman was breathing after the fall and was rushed to the hospital where she was declared brought dead. “The mother was in their flat when the incident occurred,” said a police officer on condition of anonymity.

Police said they are waiting for the Wadilal’s mother to recover from the shock before asking further questions. A case of accidental death report has been registered.

Title: Navi Mumbai: Man booked for giving triple talaq over Rs 10 lakh dowry
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Representative image

NAVI MUMBAI: A 28-year-old woman has lodged a police complaint alleging that her husband had given her a talaq notice and later instant divorce by uttering ‘talaq’ thrice at his Vashi residence last month. She also alleged that her husband and three in laws harassed her for Rs 10 lakh dowry.

It is the fourth case under the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019, in Mumbai metropolitan region, and the second in Navi Mumbai.

“The woman had initially lodged a complaint with Ambernath police on December 14, as she had moved back with her parents. On December 31, the case was transferred to Vashi police station as she alleged that her husband, aged 30, had given her triple talaq at his Vashi home,” said senior inspector Sanjeev Dhumal of Vashi police station. “After recording her statement, we will summon the four accused to ascertain whether her husband had uttered ‘talaq’ thrice.”

In her statement to Ambernath police, the woman said soon after their marriage in June 2014, her husband, his mother, brother and sister started abusing and assaulting her, and demanded dowry. Dhumal said, “She alleged that her husband demanded that she get Rs 10 lakh from her parents or leave his house with her child. She said last month her husband gave her a divorce notice and uttered ‘talaq’ thrice. Even after counselling, her husband and in-laws were reluctant to take her back, so she approached the police.”

The husband, his mother, brother and sister have been booked under Section 4 of the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019, along with IPC sections 498A (husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), 406 (criminal breach of trust), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace) and 506 (criminal intimidation).

Three such cases were registered in 2019. On August 1, Thane police had booked a Mumbra resident who had given triple talaq to his wife via WhatsApp on November 30, 2018. In the second case, Nagpada police booked a 39-yearold man for giving instant talaq to his dietician wife in November 2018. In the third case registered at Kharghar police station in November 2019, a 20-year-old TYBCom student claimed that her 28-year-old husband had divorced her by uttering ‘talaq’ thrice at his Kurla home in May.

Title: Gujarat tribals make room for mushroom
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Villagers, school children and even forest department employees from around 100 villages have been trained to ... Read More

VADODARA: Mushrooms may be considered gourmet, but in central Gujarat 's tribal belt, this is becoming a staple in many kitchens.

Thanks to the efforts by a city-based activist who introduced mushrooms to the tribal people in around 100 villages on an experimental basis, some farmers have not only warmed up to the new-found fungiculture, but are also consuming the exotic product.

Considering malnutrition - the biggest problem in tribal areas of the state - activist Anil Satapathy trained these rustic tillers on how to grow mushrooms besides teaching them how to cook and eat them too. The nutritious food item is being cooked as in organised community events to encourage more acceptance and consumption.

Satapathy, who leads the Rural Institute for Stimulating Tribal Areas (RISTA), said that mushrooms are rich in nutrition and can be grown easily in mediums like paddy straw, grass, cotton crop waste and other material. "If one grows different varieties of mushrooms, one can cultivate them throughout the year," he explained.

The Savli Technology and Business Incubator by the Gujarat State Biotechnology Mission has provided the activist space where he prepares the spawns for paddy straw, oyster and milky mushrooms and supplies them to villagers.

The activist said he has demonstrated the technique to villagers, school children and even forest department employees from around 100 villages in Dahod, Panchmahal, Chhota Udepur, Narmada and Vadodara districts so far.

Title: Karnataka’s Jammu and Kashmir luxury hotel plan hits snag
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Karnataka tourism minister CT Ravi

BENGALURU: Three months after it was mooted, the Karnataka government’s ambitious proposal to run a luxury hotel in Jammu & Kashmir has failed to take off due to technical reasons that include the absence of internet and mobile services in J&K and the change in the status of J&K from a state to Union Territory.

The state government had proposed a luxury hotel in J&K soon after the Centre revoked special status to the state in September last year. Tourism minister CT Ravi had written to then J&K governor Satyapal Malik and outlined the state government’s intent.

Karnataka State Tourism Development Corporation (KSTDC) was to run the hotel. Speaking to TOI, KSTDC MD Kumar Pushkar said the government plans to buy 10 to 15 acres of land in J&K.

“We want to facilitate Karnataka tourists who frequent J&K for religious events like the Amarnath Yatra,” Pushkar said. “More than commercial viability, we are looking at a property to serve citizens. However, we are yet to hear from the J&K administration.”

Officials said the communication blockade had hampered efforts. “We were unable to reach officials to know the status of our proposal. This included the governor’s office,” said a senior official.

However, Pushkar said he managed to get in touch with the director of tourism for J&K a few days ago and there has been some development on the proposal. “If required, a team from Karnataka will visit J&K for further negotiation,” Pushkar said.

The other major problem was the change in the status of J&K. “The minister’s first letter was addressed to the state government of J&K. Now, they are changing it to a UT and they have asked for a fresh process.”

“The J&K governor had in fact given me an appointment in this regard on December 20, but due to anti-CAA protests, the meet was cancelled,” Ravi said.

Title: Ahmedabad: Man poses as woman, blackmails man with nudes
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A man, pretending to be a woman on social media, would convince men to share naked pictures of themselves with him and then blackmail them. A 29-year-old city-based man fell into this trap and coughed up Rs 46,010 through cash, e-wallets and gift vouchers. He finally had enough and lodged a complaint with city cyber cell.

DCP cyber cell Rajdeepsinh Jhala said this is the first such case they have encountered in which a man was blackmailed by a man who posed as a woman on social media.

"We have registered an offence under Section 384 of the IPC for extortion along with Sections 66-C and 67 of the IT Act. We have asked internet service providers for the IP address of the device through which at least four fake IDs of women were created to ensnare men," added Jhala.

According to the FIR lodged by the complainant, when he was doing his MCA in 2011, he came across a social media ID ostensibly belonging to a woman. They began chatting regularly. After a while, the person on the other end propositioned the man and then asked for nude photos of him, which the complaint sent to the ID.

The FIR states that the 29-year-old man soon started receiving extortion messages on social media, saying that if he did not pay up, his nude pictures would be sent to his mother and sister. The complainant was shocked to learn that the ID to which he sent his nude pictures was being run by a man and not a woman.

"Afraid of the consequences, the complainant first deposited Rs 15,000 into the bank account specified by the person behind the fake ID. The complainant deactivated his social media ID after that," said a senior cyber cell official.

Title: Bengaluru: Mom gives away baby boy, runs to police out of guilt
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Wracked with guilt over having given away her 53-day-old boy through illegal adoption after finding it difficult to raise him, a 35-year-old assistant professor knocked on the doors of police, pleading that she be reunited with her child.

Police managed to rescue the infant from a Mysuru couple on Thursday and handed him over to the Child Welfare Committee (CWC) in Bengaluru. The birth parents and the man who led them to the Mysuru couple were charged with selling the baby.

Banashankari residents Raksha (name changed) and Suresh (name changed), engineer with a private company, were blessed with a boy on October 23. With no one else to take care of the child, the couple employed domestic helps. But with the workers quitting one by one, the couple struggled to focus at work.

Upset, the couple decided to give away the child to someone in need. They came across a man, Shiv Raj (name changed), who assured them he would solve their problem. Raksha insisted the adoptive parents are childless, educated and financially stable.

On December 13, Shiv phoned the couple and said he had found the right adoptive parents. Around 5pm on December 16, Raksha and Suresh handed over their son to a man, his wife and another senior citizen — who had come in two cars — near Janata Bazaar, Banashankari III Stage. The trio said they would take good care of the child but the couple shouldn’t seek their whereabouts.

After returning home, Raksha began to suffer from guilt pangs. The couple called Shiv on phone, who said he was not aware of the child’s whereabouts. She repeatedly called him but he said he was only a middleman and asked her to file a police complaint.

On Tuesday, Raksha approached CK Achukattu police and filed a complaint. Admitting that she had committed a mistake, she requested cops to trace her child. Incidentally, hers was the last FIR to be booked by city police in 2019.

“Raksha and Suresh are professionals and couldn’t devote enough time to the child. It appears there was no money involved. We have booked the couple and Shiv under sections 80 (any person or organisation offers/gives/receives child without following adoption procedures), 81 (any person who sell/buys child) and 87 (abetment) of the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015. We are probing all angles,” a police officer said.

“Raksha keeps changing her statement. All those involved will have to appear before the CWC,” the officer added.

Title: Bigg Boss 13: Sidharth Shukla tells ‘Rashami and my journey was smooth until I decided to cut off’
Content: In the last night’s episode (January 2), Sidharth Shukla nonchalantly asks Shefali Jariwala, Paras Chhabra and Mahira Sharma to tell what could have gone wrong between him and Rashami Desai . He tells them to give an outsider's perspective.Paras tells that he knows and Sidharth asks if he knows Rashami’s version from her. Paras says they had a connection and he knows things. Nothing ever happened. They used to talk and had a great connection.Things became sour when Sidharth decided to cut off and stop talking, such rumours started to appear. Sidharth also tells that is the reason why Rashami can’t argue with him properly in the house.He also finds it futile to fight over a fact which never happened.For the uninitiated, Sidharth and Rashami were a part of the show Dil Se Dil Tak . Title: Day 3 of 7-day weight loss plan to drop a dress size
Content:
FacebookTwitterPintrest

Today is the day 3 of our 7-day workout plan to help you drop a dress size. We hope the new year and new beginnings have you in high spirits to accomplish your weight loss goals.DAY 1: New Year, New Workout: Day 1 of 7-day weight loss plan to drop a dress size DAY 2: New Year, New Workout: Day 2 of 7-day weight loss plan to drop a dress size Today’s workout is sprint training, which helps you burn fat, build muscles and boost your BMR (Basal Metabolic Rate). This training method is becoming the recommended choice for cardiovascular exercises. It’s better because studies have shown that short bursts of running are more efficient than long walks or jogs.Fitness expert, Kamal Chhikara will take you through sprint training while explaining about the workout in detail.- Sprint workout is typically done on resistance bike.- It can also be done on any equipment that allows a rapid change in the speed, like rowing or cross-trainer.- You have to perform the exercise for a total of 20 minutes, in which you will sprint for 8 minutes and 12 minutes will be the active rest (where you don’t stop but slow down).- 60 repetitions of 8 seconds’ sprint with maximum effort interspersed with 12 seconds of active rest (slowing down but not stopping) after every 8 seconds.- If you do not work out regularly, perform the exercise under an expert’s supervision.

Title: Karnataka: ASHA workers to go on indefinite strike from today
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Over 30,000 Accredited Social Health Activist ( ASHA ) workers from across Karnataka will begin an indefinite protest here on Friday asking the government to fulfil their demands, including immediate release due incentives.

The workers will march from KSR Railway Station to Freedom Park at 11am. The dharna at Freedom Park will start at 12pm.

The indefinite day and night agitation is organised by the Karnataka State United Asha Workers ' Union.

The workers' demands include a minimum monthly honorarium of Rs 12,000 and delinking of the Asha incentives to Asha Soft or Reproductive Child Health (RCH) Portal. They have demanded immediate disbursal of incentives due for over 15 months in a single payment.

Title: Gujarat: Cops as decoy labourers raid gambling den, nab 14
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Tact wins where might fails — a proverb that cops successfully employed while stepping into Jangleshwar locality, notoroius as the gambling hub of the city. What really challenges the authorities here are the the myriad of labyrinthine lanes criss-crossing the locality that makes a raid almost impossible task.

However, cops handle the odds smartly this time and nabbed 14 gamblers, some of them with criminal history, on Thursday.

On almost every previous raid, gamblers disappeared in to these alleys even before cops could enter the forbidden territory.

Informers would be posted at all vantage points in the hub that kingpins ruled who would keep them posted on all movements. At the slightest hint of trouble, dens would immediately shut down and gamblers disappear from the scene.

But on Thursday, policemen knew exactly how to play the same game, but cop style. They formed three teams of nine personnel dressed up as weather-beaten labourers.

“Each team consisted of three officers We had a google map of the the gambling den which we fed into our team members’ cellphones. All the teams were instructed to reach the target separately, so as not to attract unnecessary suspicion,” said V K Gadhvi, inspector with Bhaktinagar police station.

While one team went by Nadoda Nagar route, the other two teams crossed Aji River. Cops in mufti also used autorickshaws and cycles instead of police vehicles.

“When we reached our target — the house of Bashir Jesani (38) — we heard the gamblers shouting inside. We broke open the rear and the front doors of the house simultaneously and entered. All the 14 gamblers didn’t have the time or the escape route to flee and were caught,” narrated Gadhvi.

The police recovered Rs 2.58 lakh cash, dices, 15 cellphones, two two-wheelers, one SUV and one car from the accused.

Those arrested included Jesani, Tanvir Shishangia (38), Jahid Parekh (30), Rafiq Thariyani (34), Bhupat Basia (49), Shabir Kalar (36), Vasim Baloch (25), Rafiq Lakhani (40), Mansukh Kachhathiya (35) and Mahaveersinh Jadeja (30). They all are history-sheeters having been booked in different crimes in the past.

Title: Hyderabad Rain: Hyderabad sees second wettest January day since 1922
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Water-logging near Durgam Cheruvu following Thursday’s rain.

HYDERABAD: The city experienced its second wettest day in January after 1922 by receiving an average rainfall of 36.8 mm up to 8.30 pm. As per to the India Meteorological Department figures, the city received highest rainfall of 93.2 mm on January 3, 1922.

Meteorologists said thunderstorm activity was likely to continue till January 4 following which it would subside making way for cold wave conditions. “The minimum temperature is expected to increase in parts of Telangana by 2-3 degrees celsius in the coming days, while maximums will subside due to rains and cloud cover.

From January 4, weather activities will start to clear up and minimums will once again fall in Telangana,” read a weather report issued by Skymet, an independent weather forecasting agency.

As predicted by Indian Meteorological Department (IMD), Hyderabad, thunderstorm activity intensified during evening hours with the city experiencing cold and damp weather conditions. According to Telangana State Development Planning Society (TSDPS), Mondamarket in Secunderabad received highest rainfall of 52.3 mm followed by 43 mm in Begumpet and 37.8 mm in Seethaphalmandi. The rainfall was triggered by a cyclonic circulation over northern Telangana. “Currently, the city is witnessing southeasterly winds which have higher moisture level. This moisture results in formation of rain-bearing clouds which caused the thunderstorm activity,” said Raja Rao, Indian Meteorological Department The merging of winds is instrumental for cloud formation and subsequent rainfall.

Few hours of rainfall led to water logging in many areas thereby causes traffic snarls. Waterlogging was reported at I-Labs U-turn to Nectar Garden towards COD junction, Palak Hotel near Erragadda metro station towards Kukatpally. Both the spots were cleared by GHMC and the Cyberabad traffic police. Despite rains, city recorded maximum temperature of 28.4 degrees celsius and mininum temperature of 20.4 degrees celsius. The city is witnessing a warm winter this year with mercury levels hovering four to five degrees celsius above normal.

“During the last 24 hours, lowest minimum temperature of 19.3 degrees celsius was recorded at Kapra and highest maximum temperature of 30.5 degrees celsius at Asifnagar (Hyderabad) district,” read a weather report issued by Telangana State Development Planning Society.

Title: 6 years on, Kedarnath survivor reunited with kin
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

File photo

DEHRADUN: For over six years, Mobin Ansari — a 62-yearold woman hailing from Sitarganj in Uttarakhand ’s Udham Singh Nagar district — had been leading the life of a widow after her husband Jameel Ahmed Ansari went missing and was presumed dead in the 2013 Kedarnath tragedy, which left many dead and several untraceable.

However, on the last day of 2019, Mobin got a video call from Chamoli and to her surprise, it was from her husband. He had been located by police during the ‘ Operation Smile ’ conducted by them to trace missing persons at a shelter home at Gopeshwar in Chamoli, where he had been living for the past few years with his memory all but gone. Police officials managed to trace his whereabouts after putting up his picture on social media. The 65-year-old was reunited with his family on New Year’s Day.

Cops questioned Kedarnath flood survivor in 2016

Piecing together Jameel’s story, sub-inspector Nitin Bisht, who is handling ‘Operation Smile’ in Chamoli district, told TOI that Jameel, 65, was working as a labourer in Lambagad in June 2013.

When disaster struck, he was carried away in the currents of the Alaknanda and had no recollection of what happened thereafter, Bisht said. Bisht said that police officials had also questioned Jameel in 2016 when they spotted him in the shelter home. “At that time, he identified himself as Zaheer Khan . In the first week of December last year, we visited the home again and this time, he said his name was Jameel.”

Jameel’s picture was circulated among social media groups and his nephew identified him. On January 1, Mobin and her elder son went to Gopeshwar, where police handed over Jameel to them.

Title: To boost artificial intelligence adoption, Telangana pairs industry, academia
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Minister KT Rama Rao inaugrates Telangana's Year of AI in the city on Thursday. (Left) IT secretary Jayesh Ran... Read More

HYDERABAD: The Telangana government on Thursday declared 2020 as the year of artificial intelligence (AI) and inked nine memoranda of understanding (MoUs) with IT players and educational institutions to develop various use cases as well as conduct research on the application of AI and creation of talent pool in this area.

Intel, Public Health Foundation of India (PHFI) and IIIT- Hyderabad jointly inked a pact with the government for setting up a research centre in applied AI in healthcare and mobility.

Speaking at the event, Nivruti Rai, country head, Intel India, said, “AI is going to make a $13 trillion addition to the world economy, if you think AI, there are five characteristics of data that are essential to drive its success – quality, quantity, depth, access and diversity and India has it all.” She said Intel will be working with IIIT-Hyderabad, PHFI and state government to leverage AI to broaden the access of quality healthcare to masses.

The state also inked a pact with Nvidia that will be setting up a high performance computing AI centre in Hyderabad. The government entered into a MoU with IIT-Kharagpur to set up an AI centre of excellence and research and development park in the city. Telangana will also be partnering with Adobe, IIT Hyderabad for capacity building in AI.

“As we all know, machine readable data is the core of any AI/ML algorithm. Realizing that availability of quality data would be a key differentiator, we had launched the open data policy and published data related to about 20 departments on the open data platform... The aim, going forward, is to democratise seamless availability of data by creating population scale curated public data sets, especially in the areas of mobility, healthcare, agriculture and e-governance, leading to better innovation, governance and successful business outcomes,” Telangana IT minister KT Rama Rao said, adding that Telangana would create India AI Data Trust that would be a resource centre of such data sets.

He also added the state would work with partners to make available a high-performance AI Computing (HPAIC) infrastructure for startups and research centers.

Title: NGO survey reveals rising burden of diseases in Hyderabad
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Non-communicable diseases like diabetes, hypertension, cardiovascular problems, cancer, and kidney ailments take a heavy toll on the health profile of the residents living in old city of Hyderabad. A health survey by an NGO in areas south of the river Musi has revealed that about 12% of the adults have diabetes and about 20% have reported hypertension while 5% suffer from heart diseases.The NGO, Helping Hand Foundation (HHF), in its survey report released on Thursday said the incidence of cancer is increasing in the city. About one-third of the cancer cases in Telangana are from Hyderabad. The cancer of head and neck, particularly oral cancer in men, breast cancer in women and blood cancer in children below 5 years is causing concern, the report said.“Pulmonary and extrapulmonary TB is also alarmingly high in teenage population of old city. An estimated 600 to 700 new cases of TB are reported every month,” the report said, adding that one in three families with one or more members with noncommunicable diseases are under the burden of loans or are in debt due to borrowing money to meet medical expenses.Helping Hand Foundation managing trustee Mujtaba Hasan Askari said about 25% of households in old city slums suffer from chronic illnesses. Many students of higher education are forced to discontinue studies to take up menial jobs to support the families.He said about 13,000 patients from poor sections of society were provided medical help during 2019 in government hospitals. Patients were encouraged to approach government hospitals, and this had helped the poor families save about ₹7 crore during the year.The rising burden of noncommunicable diseases is putting a huge amount of mental and financial stress on the common man from the city and by linking them to the public health system a great amount of justice is being done, Mujtaba Hasan added.As part of the survey, HHF volunteers visited houses and hospitals in the city, particularly in old city, to collect data about various health issues vis-à-vis the financial burden the families are subjected to due to non-communicable diseases. Several health checkup camps were set up and data collected during such exercises were computed to arrive at the burden of disease in old city and other parts of Hyderabad.

Title: CAA Protest Chennai: Organiser, NGO hit back at top cop
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

File photo of a woman drawing kolam on road

CHENNAI: Anti-corruption NGO Arappor Iyakkam on Thursday condemned Chennai police commissioner A K Vishwanathan for referring to the NGO while talking about kolam protests. The NGO alleged that it was purposefully done to somehow connect it with Pakistan and tarnish its image among the public.

During a press meet on Wednesday, Vishwanathan alleged that one protester, Gayatri Khandhadai, was being probed for her ‘Pakistani links’ based on her social media activity. He alleged that she was in touch with groups such as Popular Front of India (PFI) and Arappor Iyakkam.

“This is part of a witchhunt launched against Arappor and its office-bearers for our continued expose about corruption in Greater Chennai Corporation . Vishwanathan has misused the police force to file a series of false FIRs against us,” Jayaram Venkatesan, convenor of Arappor Iyakkam, said. Indoor meetings of the NGO have been stopped and hall owners have been asked not to give space, Arappor said.

Vishwanathan told TOI that several FIRs had been filed against Arappor Iyakkam and its office-bearers. “They are facing trial in these cases. They have raised false allegations in the past and these allegations are also false,” he said.

Arappor questioned why Vishwanathan did not name principal opposition party DMK while speaking about parties that condemned Chennai police’s arrest of kolam protestors. “Is it because he will lose his chance of becoming DGP if DMK comes to power in 2021,” the statement said.

Arappor said last June, Vishwanathan asked Jayaram to meet local bodies minister S P Velumani to sort out issues and that the commissioner was under pressure from the minister to deny permission to Arappor’s events.

Title: Govt eyes Rs 30,000 crore via cash management bill
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

File photo

MUMBAI: Faced with redemptions of government securities (G-Secs) aggregating Rs 1.35 lakh crore till January 16, the government on Thursday said it will auction cash management bills (CMBs) on Monday to mop up Rs 30,000 crore. This is the second CMB in the last two weeks. The government usually issues CMBs to tide over situations of temporary liquidity mismatch.

RBI data shows that on Thursday the government had a redemption worth Rs 61,000 crore, while another worth Rs 74,000 crore is due on January 16. To meet this large demand for liquidity, the government is auctioning CMBs, bond dealers said. On December 31, the government had mobilised Rs 30,000 crore through CMBs of 76-day tenure. The CMBs that will be auctioned on Monday will have a tenure of 70 days, the RBI release showed.

During the day, the central bank also announced its third ‘operation twist’, a move in which the government’s banker will buy G-Secs of long and medium tenure worth Rs 10,000 crore and at the same time sell government bonds of less than one year tenure. This is the third such operation by the RBI in as many weeks, aimed at pulling down the 10-year benchmark yield, which is one of the main determinants of the lending rates by banks.

Since February this year, the RBI has cut interest rate five times, by a total of 135 basis points (100 basis points = 1 percentage point). However, just before the first operation twist was announced on December 19, the aggregate decline in yield on the 10-year G-Sec was 80bps — from 7.55% in early-February to 6.75% on that day. Even after two such operations by the RBI, the benchmark yield on 10-year G-Secs on Thursday closed at 6.51%, translating to a decline of 24bps in the last three weeks.

Title: Central metro station to get parking space in two weeks
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

File photo of a Chennai Metro train

CHENNAI: It has been nearly a year since the city’s largest underground interchange metro station at Central opened for service, but commuters are still struggling to find space to park their vehicles as the planned parking lot is yet to be opened. But according to CMRL, there will soon be some relief, as an underground parking space is expected to open by mid-January. The lot will be able to hold 100 cars and 300 two-wheelers at a time.

“We are fixing glass panes at the entrance of the parking lot. It will be ready in another 15 days,” an official said. Central metro became operational in February 2019 when the last leg of the 45km phase-1 from Washermenpet to AG-DMS via Central metro was thrown open to public.

Till now, metro rail commuters at Central struggle to find parking space and end up leaving their vehicles either at Central railway station or near the Ripon Buildings. The hassle of finding space is even worse for those arriving at the station for the first time, since they are not aware that the parking lot is not ready. “It was my first time at the metro and I went around the junction in front of Central station thrice looking for parking space, until a CMRL staff told me the parking lot is not open. It was a struggle as it was peak hour traffic,” said S Harish of Vepery.

The parking lot under construction is on the concourse level of Central metro and is linked to the entrance through a ramp. Once opened, officials said it can be used both by metro rail commuters as well as others. Passengers taking suburban trains at Moore Market Complex or outstation trains at Central Railway Station too could use the facility, as the parking lot is closer to these transport hubs. Passengers to Park and Park Town stations could also use the facility as it is only a pedestrian subway away.

Several other stations along the two corridors of phase-1do not have parking space.

On Thursday, a hydraulic system that can hold five twowheelers at a height of about 9ft, with space for five to be parked at the ground level was opened at Meenambakkam metro station on a trial basis. “We will wait to see its safety and response from commuters for a month before extending it to other stations. We will build a level between street level and concourse for parking in station,” an official said.

Title: Passengers at Rajiv Gandhi International Airport set to cross 22 million in 2019-20
Content:
Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) has emerged as the best-connected facility in south and central Indi... Read More

HYDERABAD: With 55 non-stop domestic destinations under its wings, Rajiv Gandhi International Airport ( RGIA ) has emerged as the best-connected facility in south and central India, latest records show. It beat Bengaluru, which reportedly has about 52 connections.The city’s airport hit a new high in annual footfall during the last financial year, with the figure touching 21.36 million, as against 18.30 million recorded during the previous corresponding year. Sources say, the yearly passenger movement through RGIA might cross 22 million this year. “In fact, RGIA is currently expanding to handle 34 million passengers per annum,” stated a release issued by the GMR Hyderabad International Airport Ltd (GHIAL).Commissioned in 2008, the airport has eight domestic and 21 international carriers operating out of it. The facility operates 25 passenger airlines connecting 71domestic and international destinations.“Given the size and scale of operations of Hyderabad Airport, we see it as a gateway airport to a vast region stretching into entire northern Karnataka, south-eastern Maharashtra, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Andhra Pradesh. We have identified over 15 cities which we are targeting through our ‘Fly via Hyderabad’ campaign. Our vision in the next five to 10 years is to become a big transit hub,” said a source.

Title: Telangana records 13% growth in December GST collection
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: In a good news for the state reeling under economic slowdown, GST collection data released by Union finance ministry shows that Telangana recorded 13% growth in GST collection in December 2019, as compared to December 2018.As per the data, in December 2018, GST collections were ₹3,014 crore, whereas in 2019, the collections went up to ₹3,420 crore. Though Tamil Nadu and Kerala are ahead of Telangana, officials attributed the increase to better GST compliance by traders and companies and good business growth. “Development happens due to various reasons, we feel that things will get back to normal, this is natural,” said planning board vice-chairman B Vinod Kumar.Meanwhile, the country’s GST revenue during December 2019 from domestic transactions showed an impressive growth of 16% as compared to 2018. The neighbouring state of Andhra Pradesh witnessed a 11% growth in competitive figures. In December 2018, AP’s GST collections were ₹2,049 crore and in December 2018, the collections stood at ₹2,265 crore.Experts said that this could be a good sign for the state, stating that if the GST collection grows further in the next two to three months, it would mean that the economy is recovering from the slowdown. “Last month, the government made strict measures for GST collection, in general, in December the collection improved due to festivities,” said financial expert and former IDBI director Narsimha Murthy.Experts further observed that the GST collection indicates slow growth, but added that many other factors will come into play which will help the GDP grow as both GST and GDP growth are interlinked.

Title: ATF Price Hike in Chennai: ATF price hike could force airlines to avoid refuelling in Chennai
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Fuel price varies from one airport to the other because state governments charge different slabs of tax.

CHENNAI: An increase in price of aviation turbine fuel (ATF) has made Chennai the second most expensive city to buy jet fuel, which can force airlines to avoid refuelling in the city airport. This will also lead to a hike in air fares.

ATF fuel prices were increased by 2.6% on January

1. This makes the one kilo litre of ATF to cost ₹65, 619 in Chennai airport while it costs ₹70,588 in Kolkata, the highest in a metro airport. Prices are lower in Mumbai and Delhi.

The price was ₹63,830 per kilo litre in Chennai as of December 1, 2018. Now, airlines will have to pay ₹1,789 more. An A320 type plane uses around six tonnes of fuel for a short domestic flight.

This is expected to encourage airlines to lift fuel from other airports and not from Chennai. The process called tankering or carrying more fuel than needed for a trip will go up, said a pilot.

"If an aircraft needs only six tonnes of fuel, the pilot will try to carry 12tonnes depending on the passenger and cargo load so that the next sector can also be flown without refueling in Chennai," he added.

This practice is expected to increase in the coming days as most of the domestic carriers fly multiple routes using the same plane. Since, Mumbai and Delhi is the hub for airlines to park their planes as the airports have more parking bays than in Chennai, there is a chance that pilots will carry fuel from Mumbai.

"This is likely to impact the load of the plane and quantity of cargo may have to be reduced to carry fuel. However, flights flying from Chennai to Delhi may have to carry extra fuel than they usually carry because air congestion caused by fog is leading to delays and diversions. This will be a loss," said an airline official.

The fuel price varies from one airport to the other because state governments charge a tax. The tax is higher in Tamil Nadu. There was a call to make prices or taxes uniform across all airports.

An official of the Airports Authority of India (AAI) said that "The state government has reduced the tax for fuel at small airports like Coimbatore. But, in Chennai they charge high because refueling is high and there is scope for earning more money."

Air Passengers Association of Indi national president D Sudhakara Reddy said "Air fares are bound to go up. Already airlines are incurring loss because of the mess caused by air congestion in Delhi. The congestion is having a cascading effect of delays at all airports. This will add to it. Its surprising that they are increasing the jet fuel price though price of crude has reduced from $68 per barrel to $66."

Title: Man dies of electric shock in Selaiyur
Content:
This story is from January 3, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A 25-year-old man who latched on to an electric pole for support while crossing a water-logged stretch in Selaiyur on Thursday was electrocuted.

Police said Senthil Kumar, a resident of the Tambaram Railway Quarters, was an employee on an online shopping firm. The incident happened at 1.30am on Velachery Main Road, just a few metres from the Selaiyur police station.

An electrician who was involved in removing a series of decorative lights set up at the Selaiyur police station for the New Year celebrations saw Senthil Kumar jumping over the stagnant patch of water. Senthil lost control and held an electric pole when he was thrown away.

The electrician immediately rushed to the spot and alerted police.

Senthil died on the spot. His body was sent to the Chromepet Government hospital for postmortem. Police said power leakage from the electric pole may have caused the death.
